newsitem.title: MEXICO: Banco de Mexico reserves, assets rise.
newsitem.headline: Banco de Mexico reserves, assets rise.

text.p: Banco de Mexico said Tuesday its net international assets as of September 6, 1996, were $3.851 billion, compared with $3.701 billion on August 30. The central bank said that its net international reserves as of September 6 were $15.528 billion, compared with $15.444 billion as of August 30.
It said the increase of $150 million in international assets was due to:
- Revenues from operations with state oil firm Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex) worth $166 million
- Foreign exchange outgoings from other operations worth a net $11 million.
- A net sale of currency to the federal government worth $5 million to cover external debt service.
Banco de Mexico said the monetary base shrank by 1.625 billion pesos due to lower demand for notes and coins following last week's payment of fortnightly salaries.
The balance of the federal government's current account at the central bank rose by 3.088 billion pesos, mainly as the result of tax collection.

The central bank said it compensated for the monetary contraction caused by the increase in the government's current account balance by increasing credit to financial institutions by 801 million pesos.
The following tables detail Banco de Mexico's assets and net domestic credit. All figures are in billions of pesos, unless otherwise indicated.
*Net International Assets are defined as gross international assets minus central bank liabilities with the IMF and assets of less than a six month duration from other central banks.
